segments.text: This is an interview with Pete Hamer by Kathy Hamer on Saturday, December 3, 1988 at his home in Temple, Texas concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that alright with you?
Yes.
Okay, could you please give me your full name?
Peter Thomas Hamer.
Okay, and when and where were you born?
I was born in New York City in 1940, May 1940.
Okay, and what kind of family life did you have?
What kind of childhood?
Well...
Typical?
Well, I don't think so.
Typical to what?
Mommy and Daddy.
Daddy went to work and my mother stayed home and took care of me and my brother.
We lived mostly in apartments until I was about
15 or so, and then we bought a cheap house in a poor neighborhood, but we had a house.
And, like, you know, that's how typically, I guess it's typical.
What type of education did you have?
I still have it.
Okay.
Okay.
Yeah, well, elementary school, high school.
I went to junior college in Staten Island.
for two years.
Was your father or grandfathers in any of the wars?
No, no.
Nobody in my family was ever in the war except a great-grandfather who was in the Union Navy during the Civil War.
He was an Irish immigrant.
I saw a picture of him once.
But no, nobody else in the...
I had an uncle who was in the World War II, but he was
married my mother's sister and he was a sergeant in the army and then became a warrant officer.
Um, how and why and when did you join the military?
Well, I, how?
I went down to the recruiting office and signed up.
There were recruiting offices all over and all you had to do was
Go in there, they had nice signs hanging up.
It looked like everybody was having such a great time.
In New York, there were recruiting officers all over the place.
And how did I join up?
I went down and joined up.
I was a volunteer back when most people were draftees in the Army.
You have to understand, back in the late 50s and early 60s, the draft was still in effect.
All young men were subject to the draft.
In fact, that was a rite of passage.
When you were 18, you went down and got your draft card.
That was kind of like an ID card.
You could buy booze and drink beer in the clubs and bars and stuff like that.
So that was like a coming of age.
Here in Texas, it's getting your driver's license at age 16.
In New York, it was getting your draft card when you were 18.
That meant you could drink legally.
But the draft was still in place.
In fact, when I got into the Army,
Oh, 80, 85%, 90% of the guys that I was in the Army were draftees, guys that had, who had been drafted.
No, I was a, what do you call it, regular Army.
I didn't, I had joined up.
I wasn't drafted at all.
Why, why did you leave?
Well, you have to understand how it is to be in the,
in the lower classes in New York.
You don't have a lot of options.
You think of a, you know, in New York everything is just great.
That's the big apple of the world to us, but it isn't true.
There's a lot of barriers that exist if you don't have the dough or if you don't have the background to, to draw upon.
Nobody in my family had ever been to college.
All I ever heard from my folks was how broke they were all the time.
It was,
It wasn't hand to mouth and my father always worked, but there was almost an attitude that this noble poverty is great for you.
Buy the cheapest and make it last the longest.
I had to get out of that and I couldn't figure any other way to do it other than by joining the military and get out of New York and seeing some of the world and maybe opening some doors.
Navy, the Air Force, or Marines, whatever it was, because the Army had some really good opportunities for getting a commission, becoming a commissioned officer, and I saw that as a ticket.
So, yeah, how did I join the Recruit North?
Why did I join?
I wanted to increase the scope of my life.
It sounds corny, but it's true.
And when did I join?
I joined right after I graduated from junior college.
I'd been married about a year and a half.
February 2nd, 1962, I enlisted specifically for the infantry.
Now, that's another story.
I'd taken two years at Union College in mechanical technology, which is like the first two years of mechanical engineering.
And when I went down to the recruiting office, they had a bunch of little tests that they gave me, and I scored very high on mechanical aptitude.
Of course, I would have because of the training I just had received.
to work on the Army's research and development facility in New Mexico, White Sands, New Mexico, testing all these big missiles out.
And I was all set for that, and I thought about it.
I said, being in the Army means being a soldier, not a grease monkey.
So I went back to that same recruiting sergeant, and I said, look, change it.
Sign me up for the infantry.
So I joined the infantry.
I went on active duty, and I...
My first few years in the Army spent as an infantryman.
Did you ever expect that you'd be going to war?
Yeah.
Didn't know where or when or how.
We thought it would be in Europe.
The focus then, remember the war in Berlin in 1961?
August of 1961, the Russians put a wall up around Berlin, West Berlin.
And everybody in the world thought we were going to go to war.
and it was the Cuban Missile Crisis, remember that?
Yeah, that was in October of 62, I believe.
At that time, nobody knew where Vietnam was.
I mean, it was just, so what?
When I was in basic training, my drill instructor was Sergeant Jose Tamayo, and Sergeant Tamayo said, I can't wait till we,
get this class over, I'm going to volunteer to go to South Vietnam, he called it.
Because he knew there was something going on there, but he didn't know exactly what the name of it was.
He knew it was over in the Pacific somewhere, but he thought it would be a good career move for him to become an advisor in South Vietnam.
But now everybody's thinking Europe.
Nobody thought about Vietnam in 1961, 62.
Nobody knew where the hell it was.
There was nothing on the media about it.
It was really, you know, pop media.
Maybe in some esoteric academic journal somewhere, some Ph.D. candidate was writing an article about a marriage that was involved in Southeast Asia.
The other thing was somebody did a story about a Dr. Tom Dooley in Laos who was, apparently was killed by the communists there.
He became a martyr by the John Birch Society back then.
But no, I was thinking Europe.
Most of what focused was Europe.
How long were you in the Army before you went to Vietnam?
Okay, I joined in 62, in February 62.
I went to Vietnam in January 1968.
Early January, January 7th.
That date should be significant to you because
A couple of weeks after I got to Vietnam is when they had that Tet Offensive.
So you were there for the Tet Offensive?
Oh, yeah.
I was there for the Tet Offensive.
I was there for 11 months.
And every time we participated in the campaign, you'd get a little bronze star to put on your Vietnam service ribbon.
After 11 months, I had five of those little bronze stars.
Five major campaigns in 11 months.
And that's kind of like the invasion of Normandy every couple of months.
That's what took the campaign to where everybody's kicking up.
Now that's had a fence up.
When I got to Vietnam, everybody thought the war was over.
Yeah.
Had the bad guys on the run.
That's the basic case.
Your expectations when you got there, did you think you were not going to be there very long?
Well, I know I was going to be there for the full year.
As soon as you got off the plane, you could see that was the 51st state.
That was part of the United States with a half a million troops there.
We had to run out of the country.
We could do anything we wanted there except at night.
We got a little lonely out there in the jungle.
During the daytime, we knew we were out of the country.
Of course, we couldn't see through the dirt, and that's where all the bad guys were, was hiding underground in their tunnels and stuff.
We didn't know that.
Did you think you could win when you got there?
You thought it was going to?
be a victory for the United States?
Sure.
No doubt about it.
And it was a victory for the United States.
You think the entire war was a victory for the United States?
Sure.
Militarily.
As long as the American soldiers were there on the ground, the military of the Vietnamese could never have taken that country over.
The kids from the farms and ranches and the factories and the streets of the cities,
went over there and did a super job.
Man, they went 10,000 miles from home against popular opinion, doing their duty like John F. Kennedy said, ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country.
Full of those ideals, they went over there.
The martyred president's famous words to the young generation.
They went over there.
They shouldered that burden that the government placed upon them.
And they did a damn good job.
They kicked Charlie's ass up and down that country.
Every time that we had a contact with the North Vietnamese or the Viet Cong, we kicked their ass.
Every time.
Alright, and this one, and that country didn't fall to the North Vietnamese until every soldier from the United States went back home.
Look that up in your history book.
And that's what really stokes me.
People say we lost the war in Vietnam.
We didn't lose a damn thing in Vietnam.
We didn't lose that war at all.
What happened is the people at home lost the will to propagate the war.
So you think it could have been won if it weren't?
Oh, sure.
How many years and how much money?
No, no, no.
See, the American people don't realize what a wonderful military establishment they had.
They have officers and enlisted men who are superbly trained.
You have no idea.
In my almost 12 years of being in the Army, almost a third of that time was spent in one school or another.
So we knew how to win that war if the American people, through their government, wanted to win it.
See, that's the thing about a war.
In Vietnam, the objective, the political objective of the war was not to defeat the enemy, but to get the enemy to the negotiating table.
That was the objective of the Vietnam War.
You've been studying that.
Do you think we could have won World War II if our objective was to get Hitler to the negotiating table?
No.
to get Jorahito or Tojo to the negotiating table?
No.
The objective in those wars was the total and unconditional defeat of the enemy.
Now, could the American military accomplish that in Vietnam?
Yeah, we estimated we could do that in two weeks.
He could win the war in two weeks?
Two weeks, maximum.
How's that?
By approaching that conflict, that war, as a total war,
maneuver to get the North Vietnamese to agree to some political solution in the South.
What would be involved in a total war?
Just like, do you remember bombing Japan with nuclear weapons?
Or saturation bombing of the cities in Germany?
Total war means all of the resources of one nation are focused to commit war on another nation.
So you think we should have used nuclear weapons?
We didn't need to use nuclear weapons in North Vietnam because it's a third world country and very small.
Conventional munitions would have worked very nicely.
Didn't we use more bombs in Vietnam, though, than they did in World War II?
I want to know about that, but most of those bombs fell out where nobody lived.
So you think if we would have bombed the population?
Sure, just like we did in World War II, in Japan, and in Germany.
Unfortunately, we might have blown up Jane Fonda if we did, and we wouldn't have had the benefit of all her marvelous artistic and exercise endeavors to draw upon for this generation.
Did you do just a slight note of sarcasm?
Just a touch.
What did you think, then, of the Vietnamese people?
Well, let's go back a little further.
Okay.
You talked about
when did I join the army and why and all that kind of stuff.
Now, all of a sudden, we left out six years of my life.
Your training, your military career before Vietnam.
Sure, you want to hear that?
That's very interesting.
Okay.
Sure.
See, I was a gung-ho son of a bitch, and that's the truth.
I enlisted infantry.
When I got into basic training, after getting issued my uniform and a short haircut,
they made me an acting sergeant.
Mainly because I was bigger than everybody else.
I was six feet tall and weighed about 195 pounds.
So I was a squad leader in basic training.

And then after basic training, before I went to what they call advanced individual training, in my case it would have been special infantry school, they sent me to a two-week leadership school for guys who had shown some leadership potential.
See, the Army was testing you and cultivating you all the way
I went to this leadership school, and I graduated second in my class out of about 60 guys.
And I went to my infantry school company, and I was made a platoon leader, platoon sergeant, acting platoon sergeant.
I've been in the Army about 14, 15 weeks now, 18, 20 weeks, and I'm an acting sergeant again.
There's times that having 20 guys I'm in charge of, I've got about 60.
And I was getting pretty good at leading men.
I went over to graduate from what we called 11-11-1-1-1.
That's basic infantryman with a gun school.
And, oh, you have no idea what they trained you to do.
You think, oh, just stick them with a knife and shoot a gun off.
No.
We got to be able to shoot an M1 rifle, a World War II rifle.
an M1 rifle at 500 yards so that I could hit a man-sized target consistently at 500 yards.
That's not with a telescope on the rifle or anything, that's just with my old eyeball.
And how to navigate across unknown terrain with nothing but a map and a compass to go for miles at night.
First aid, communications,

operation of various infantry-type vehicles, supply procedures, logistics, leadership, plus a healthy dose of things that may surprise a lot of people, but at least have classes in ethics for infantrymen.
The rules of war, the Geneva Convention, the American Code of Conduct, the treatment of prisoners, what was expected of you if you should become a prisoner,
Some people would call that nothing more than propaganda, but it's not.
It's not.
You're talking about young men who were taking informative years, and as part and parcel of their training were taught technical things, but they were also taught ethical standards.
And some guys, this is the first time in their life they were ever taught ethics.
What's the right way to treat women and children?
How do you treat a prisoner of war?
What about the duties and responsibilities you have to your comrades, to your buddies?
Can you believe that?
You find it hard to believe?
It's true.
Okay, so my first duty station of all places, since I had enlisted for the infantry in Europe, they sent me to Berlin.
Now, this is where the world was watching.
I got there in July of 1962, 11 months after the Berlin Wall was put up.
I was assigned to eight company, 6th United States Infantry, 2nd Battle Group.
The Army at that time had been organized in battle groups.
It was five maneuver companies, A, B, C, D, and E. Combat Support Company, which was heavy mortars and reconnaissance.
And Headquarters Company, which is the engineers and the medics and the clerk typists in the personnel section.
Battle Group Maintenance and things like that.
Battle Group was a huge organization.
was two battle groups in Berlin, and one tank company and an artillery company, and we were supposed to stop the Russians, who had 25 divisions.
We always estimated that in Berlin we'd last about 30 seconds, but it'd be a hell of an interesting 30 seconds, and in Berlin that was a spit and polish outfit.
We had a parade every Saturday, and special ceremonies, but we trained real hard.
We used to run night problems, and we used to have, we had a mock sitting
and all we did was train combat in the city.
And they're doing that in Fort Hood right now.
They have a little city out there and they're trying to teach these guys that it's real difficult to fight in the city.
You can't take a foxhole and go up a street.
You have to be real.
So there was a lot of training.
We were issued M14s when I got over there.
We used to go to West Germany once a year so we could fire all our big weapons, the .50 calibers
7.62 machine guns, which we really didn't have a place to fire those in Berlin, fire the mortars and fire the artillery and participate in some other type of maneuvering.
One of the things we used to train for in Berlin was riot control.
Believe it or not, it was estimated that if the Russians wasn't going to take over the city, there'd be big riots in West Berlin.
Believe it or not, there was a tremendous population, part of the population of West Berlin back in the early 60s that were pro-communist, that were Russian sympathizers.
Sounds strange, but so we felt that there was going to be an effort by the Russians to take over West Berlin by force.
The spearhead was going to be these civilians who would propagate internal unrest, if you will.
So I was in Berlin, I went all the way up to PFC when I was in Berlin.
I got a little distant, but I could read and write fairly well, because I had two years of college, so I went special duty to the battle group headquarters, and I became a sports writer.
I was at PFC, and I wrote little articles for the newspaper.
I was still on the literature unit, but they wanted to put me in there.
After about a year of that, I finally got an appointment to go to Austin Candidate School at Fort Benning.
I had to apply for that.
So I returned about a year later, I guess it was in the summer of 1964 on a troop ship.

I went over on a troop ship, came back on a troop ship and that's a whole, that's a whole new story I could tell you about taking a train from Bremerhaven, Germany all the way across East Germany and to Berlin at night and seeing the Russians as a young fella seeing us all for the first time.
That's another story.
But coming back from the United States, when I came back on a troop ship,
the sailing on the, into New York Harbor, Army, Navy, Army carrier, sailing under the Verrazano Regiment, it was still under construction at that time.
Most of the guys that were on that troop ship were being discharged from the military, from the Army, going home.
Not me, I was just getting started.
So here I was with about two years under my belt and I was looking forward to going to OCS.
I was in infantry officer school at Fort Benning, Georgia.
And that's the next stop.
I was married at the time I joined the Army, incidentally.
Your mom and I lived in Berlin in a bombed out building, right near the German border.
We had to take baths together because that's all the hot water we could eat.
Really?
But it was nice.
We had a little dog with us, kept us warm.
Coldest winter in a hundred years.
The Baltic Sea froze that year.
It was like being in the North Pole.
But that wasn't very hard for me.
A lot of hardship always broke.
You tend to regress those things.
You remember the good things.
And it was great.
So, off I am to Fort Benning, Georgia to go to infantry officer school.
Again, this whole focus of the American army is still on the conventional war in Europe, the sub-nuclear war in Europe.
You believe that?
This is 1963.
Vietnam is nine years old already, because that thing started with Eisenhower in 1954.
Nine years, no wait, even though we're Vietnam I.
Now that was an eye-opener going to Fort Benning.
Why?
You ever hear of the Green Berets?
Mm-hmm.

In my, here I am, I got a whole year as an infantry private under my belt, half the time was spent either in a parade or right banging on a typewriter doing sports columns for the battle group newspaper.
I'm still a private, PFC E3, RA 12656209, still
I want an appointment to go to OCS.
And I check in.
I see all these guys, staff sergeants, sergeant first class, buck sergeants, green berets, paratroopers out of the 101st or 82nd Airborne Division.
Some sharp, tough guys from 10, 15 years, some of them.
Unbelievable.
And we're talking about some guys who had been
CIA type kind of like one of the guys, Herman Halteman, big guy, he was 34 years old, sergeant for his class, Green Beret.
He got a special waiver because of his age to go to Oxford Candidate School.
And this guy had been working for the CIA for years in Eastern Europe.
He spoke German, Russian, Hungarian, Czechoslovakian.
He had like four or five hundred
Second Lieutenant.
Interesting.
Scary.

Well, when you get to OCS, they take all your stripes and ribbons and everything, and everybody wears the same uniform, so you can't tell whether the guys, the next gentleman I got there just turned slob like myself.
Were you pretty gun-hard?
Oh, yeah.
Everybody was.
Now, Austin County School is six months long, and about half of the guys drop out.
They can't take the stripes.
They can't take the pressure.
We used to call it pressure
is to place you under enormous stress, because war, combat, is a lot of stress.
Some people get stressed out if they break the shoelace.
And those kind of guys, they couldn't hack it as an officer.
You know, you start as second lieutenant, you're responsible for the lives of 40 guys.
As a company commander, you're responsible for about 150, 180 guys.
A battalion commander, running from 800 to 1,000,
brigade commander, maybe 5,000 guys.
Division commander, anywhere from 12 to 24,000 guys.
So, you gotta, the one thing that they emphasized at OCS was responsibility, responsibility, responsibility.
Responsibility to the nation and responsibility to your men.
And you can't fulfill those responsibilities if you
Blow your gourd if you feel icebergs.
You've got to be able to take a lot of heat, and that's what they throw at you, and that's the reason for it.
And you want to talk about training.
That school is six months long.
Did you feel it prepared you well for Vietnam?
Oh, yeah, sure.
It prepared me well for the rest of my life.
Sure.
Did they teach you anything about guerrilla warfare?
Sure.
Sure, what do you think?
And at Fort Benning, besides running, they call it the infantry school.
What is guerrilla warfare?
Nothing more than infantry tactics on a small unit level.
We studied Chairman Mao and his principles of guerrilla warfare.
You've got to know your enemy, right?
We studied the Russian partisan actions in World War II.
We studied a lot of things.
We studied Quantrell and his Raiders in the Civil War and how they used various guerrilla tactics.
We also, as students, would study other approaches to warfare, like warfare being an extension of political objectives.
The one thing that we came to realize
when it came to warfare.
That would be very prophetic later on in the early 70s.
But getting back to Fort Benning was great training.
And you graduated from there as a second lieutenant, and you felt in your mind, you knew that there was nothing that you could not achieve.
That's not much self-confidence.
We figured half of your peer group has dropped out because of lack of motivation or self-discipline or inability to cope with stress.
That means those who did graduate were pretty damn tough and tell you how down-to-earth I was.
I was a pretty good student.
I graduated, I guess, in the upper third of my class and that's, that's pretty good academically.
I excelled at some of the technical subjects, and I was very good at communications.
I enjoyed working in communications.
You give me a flashlight battery and a piece of wire, and I could talk to anybody, almost.
And I was very, very good at map and compass work.
This would prove to be important later on, because I transferred from the Infrared to Sigma Corps.
Well, when I graduated, I was planning to go to airborne ranger school.
And that's a paratrooper school and nine weeks ranger training in Fort Benning in Florida and up in the mountains of someplace out, I guess it was in Georgia.
And, but instead I went to communication school.
And that was a 10-week course in combat communication.
And I went back to Europe as a second lieutenant.
I was assigned to an infantry brigade headquarter, and I was the communications platoon leader as an infantry officer.
I was the communications platoon and headquarters company of the 3rd Brigade, 8th Division.
It was my job to maintain communications and supervise the men who actually provided the communications for the brigade headquarters.
Big job.
That's a homely story.
I spent three years in that job in Germany, in the 8th Division.
Was that in Mannheim?
That's in Mannheim, Germany.
Coleman Barracks in Sandhofen, Germany was right outside of Mannheim.
While there, towards the end of that tour, I transferred to Signal Corps and then came back to the United States and went to the Signal Officers Career Course.
I was a captain by now.
And went to the
signal officer career course at Fort Monmouth, and that's where your sister Jennifer was born in 1967 in August.
But it's an interesting thing.
By 1966 now, Vietnam was starting to build up.
This gave me quite a buildup.
And an infantry battalion, and I was in an infantry battalion.
I was a battalion communications officer.
That's on the operation staff.
It's the staff officer's job.
You know, you have a platoon of guys, but the platoon's hardly running.
While I was there, I had put in my branch transfer for Signal Corps.
So, if there's a pending personnel action, they can't, you're kind of flagged.
They can't really give you another personnel action until that one is resolved.
So, I had
I wasn't thinking Vietnam, I was just thinking long-term career, because that was definitely a career I was in for the 20 or 30 year.
The... All of a sudden, in 1966, all of our officers, even guys who had only been there a short period of time, were getting orders to go back to the States.
The 8th Division was being stripped of officers because they were constituting the
9th Infantry Division, I think it was in Fort Lewis.
They were reactivating the 9th Infantry Division and they were going to send that whole division to Vietnam.
Well, you just don't overnight get lieutenants and captains and majors.
You've got to take the ones that are there, so you strip from the other units.
Our battalion was stripped of officers.
The battalion commander was gone.
All of the staff officers were gone.
All of the captains that were company commanders were gone.
All of the lieutenants were gone.
All of a sudden, they had like one week to pack up and go to the States.
Because I had this branch transfer request in, they didn't call me.
So all of a sudden, my branch transfer comes through, and here is the weirdest company in the United States Army.
I'm the company commander.
I'm a captain or a first lieutenant.
company commander of headquarters and headquarters company of 2nd Battalion, 13th Infantry.
And I'm a signal corps lieutenant, commanding an infantry company.
That wasn't so strange.
The battalion commander was a captain who was in the adjutant general's corps.
He was a paper pusher.
And I had, in my headquarters and headquarters company,
more firepower than General George Patton had in World War II, because they had a Davy Crockett section that fired nuclear weapons.
I had, I was a first lieutenant single corps in the infantry, and I, and I had nuclear weapons capability in Germany, and my boss was a captain in the paper person corps.
Then we kind of know that something was going on, that's for sure, there's something going on in Vietnam.
The, they stripped us clean.

I transferred to a signal corps unit there for about six or eight months and we got my orders to... that's the thing about being in the signal corps, you can pick up the telephone and you can go to Washington all the time and I got the boys at the signal branch headquarters to assign me to Fort Monmouth, New Jersey to go to this school.
By then I had me captain
Mommy Jean was pregnant with Jennifer, and I didn't want to go to Vietnam while she was pregnant.
I wouldn't want to have a baby while I was away at the war.
And Monmouth was right close to where our families were in New York City.
It's only about a 40-minute drive from New York City.
So it worked out.
The signal branch boy said, yeah, we'll send you to school, and then you'll be going to Vietnam.
I said, great.
That seemed like a normal, natural career progression.
Let's take a little break here, okay?
At Fort Monmouth, we were talking about what was going on.

That was a career course and still the bulk of the training, of course, Sigma Corps being responsible for military communications was, we were trained to be managers of large communications networks and systems and all the technical things that involved in that.
But the main thrust of all our tactical and strategic type training was still the European conventional warfare.
Divisions moving here, armies moving here.
And some training time was devoted towards what was going on in Vietnam.
Surprisingly enough, as a professional officer, what was more interesting in 1967 in Vietnam was the Arab-Israeli Seven-Day War.
You remember that, in 1967?
That's where the Jews whooped everybody's butt in about a week.
Yeah, you might have heard about that, I'm sure.
We were more interested in that than we were in what was going on in Vietnam, because Vietnam still in 1967 was thought to be a so what type endeavor.
I mean, it was something that we knew as professional soldiers that if the government gave us the green light, we could wrap that up in a couple of weeks.
So you expected to be a short victory?
Yeah, if the politicians would ever get off their ass and let us go in there and win it.
What's interesting now is we're starting to hear about friends, guys we've served with, getting wounded or being killed over there.
Remember 1962 is when I came in, went to OCS in 63, 64.
A couple of my classmates from OCS had been killed in Vietnam by now.
Oh, in 67?
Well by this time, one guy was an advisor, he got killed.
Uh, Greenlightsville had three daughters, three young daughters, used to go to church with them.
He got killed over there right after I went to Europe, I heard about that.
And uh, you start hearing about guys that got, like my company commander, a guy by the name of Richardson,
in the 8th Division, in A Company.
I was a platoon leader for him, he was a company commander.
He had gone over there as a major and stepped on a landline and blew his leg off.
He wasn't killed, but his military career was over.
So you start hearing about guys now that you knew, well I said it was personal, it's not academic anymore.
Guys that you served with, professionals themselves who
Now the academics are over, now this is a real situation.
It kind of makes you think now all of a sudden you could possibly be in that situation yourself.
But Vietnam was still not the number one priority as far as the military mission was concerned.
We're still at war in Europe.
We were very concerned about that.
Europe.
Vietnam we knew, we knew to wrap that thing up in a couple of weeks.
And our strategy that we had developed

at the signal school and our strategy and tactics and peer instruction, the most viable way to bring North Vietnamese to their knees to win unconditional surrender, blockade their harbors, bomb saturate, bomb their cities, and then if you get a map of North Vietnam, you see the Red River?
The Red River is protect, the land surrounding the Red River is the crop producing lands of North Vietnam.
It's all protected by dikes.
Just go in here and blow up the dikes.
Flood them.
Flood them out and all their food production would cease.
It's very easy to close the border that they have with China because it's so small, such a small area.
So it made a problem to do that.
So we had the power to accomplish all those things.
We could send those people back to the Stone Age in two weeks.
And it was viable.
It could be done.
But we didn't have the political green light.
But yeah, that strategy could have been attained, no problem.
We never did that.
Do you think it should have been done?
Yeah, sure.
You should never commit your soldiers to fight in a war where the objective of that war is to win.
You should never commit your troops where the objective of the war is not clear, like in Vietnam.
The objective there was not clear.
The objective there was to somehow encourage the North Vietnamese to enter into a negotiated settlement.
Why do you think the United States wanted to...what was the goal?
What was the goal?
Uh-huh.
To protect the world from communism?
No.
There's a principle called precedent, which presidents, like courts, do the same thing.
The Monroe Doctrine is a classic example.
President Monroe has been dead many, many years now, but yet his doctrine is still, quote, alive.
End quote.
It's ailing, but it's still alive.
American policy had really not changed since President Eisenhower.
President Kennedy, President Johnson.
It was still a policy to somehow prevent further extensions of communist governments throughout the world.
Kind of build fences so they said, okay, what you've got, you've got, you can't get any more.
And the domino theory and if we didn't win in Vietnam, it'd be a bloodbath.
Well, that was true.
Look what happened in Cambodia.
But
There was no stated desire to achieve a military victory there.
If the President of the United States had called up the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and said, look, I'm going to take two weeks off at Camp David.
When I come back, I want that thing to be over.
Do what you think is necessary, short a nuclear war, but have this thing wound up in two weeks.
We had the resources and the military combat power to do that.
We could have wound that thing up in two weeks.
Sure.
And we wouldn't even have to fly one airplane.
Send a battleship to New Jersey over there.
And a couple of salvos would have taken out Hanoi.
They would have taken out Haiphong.
Any ship coming or going out of their ports, blown out of the water, and all of a sudden,
they're going to start losing interest in that war.
There's an old joke that says, we could win the war, but there wouldn't be anybody on the enemy's side to come to the surrender talk.
Because those people were real tough.
They didn't believe in surrendering.
We just had to kill them all.
But we could have done it.
It would have been easy.
You would think that would be fine?
Sure.
Uh-huh.
If that's what the government wanted to do, and if that was a stated objective, you betcha.
See, the guys in the Army are early on taught that they are subordinate to civilian authority.
That's always been the case in America.
We are subordinate to civilian authority.
So it's not the soldiers who wage the wars, it's the civilians.
It's the professional soldier who goes out and does the dirty work.
Are you with me?
You follow what I'm saying?
If the civilian authority's stated objectives are unclear, well, the soldier still has to go out and do what he can under the orders he's given.
So they are... What good is winning the country free from communism, though, if there's no one left to live there?
Oh, well... Are you trying to protect the people or the land area?
We're not trying to protect anybody.
We're trying to kill them all.
up north, that was the enemy.
But it was, it was ridiculous.
You're chasing some bad guys in the jungle and all of a sudden it comes in a race that says, stop, you can't go into Cambodia to pursue them.
That's ridiculous.
It's like the old days of Bonnie and Clyde where the police couldn't cross state lines.
So, you know, it was a strange situation and from the military standpoint, from a purely military standpoint, that war could have been won as a conventional war.
That is, total destruction of the enemy's ability to wage war.
We could have done that.
We had the power to do it.
But the civilian authorities didn't state that as an objective.
To this day, I'm not entirely sure what they had in mind when they committed all the soldiers there.
I'm pretty sure what it was that they wanted to show so much power, so much determination, North Vietnamese would cave in and say, okay, we'll negotiate.
Of course, we didn't understand their determination.
Do you think it would have helped to know their culture and their people better?
Yeah.
Did you know anything about them?
Well, no.
We didn't know that much about the North Vietnamese.
I mean, who did?
I mean, the French had been living there.
There had been a French colony since who knows?
The French didn't understand that those people had a very strong sense of national identity.
They didn't know that.
They thought they were just happy to be French members of a French colony.
They didn't realize that those people have been fighting over that part of the world for 4,000 years.
Everybody wants Vietnam.
You know why everybody wants Vietnam?
Rice.
Oh, do you think?
Sure.
So do you think...
Especially South Vietnam.
It's the rice bowl of the whole Asia.
They export rice like crazy.
And especially since in the 1950s, we introduced all those high yield rices, you know, that trouble of triple the acreage, the production for acreage.
It's really fascinating.
